course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Information Systems Project Management
course.description: This course covers the essential project management knowledge to ensure a successful IS/IT project.  Topics include the methods, tools and techniques for planning, budgeting, scheduling, tracking, and evaluating IS projects; PMBOK Guide; project risk assessment; IT investment decisions.

reviews.author: 職安真漢子
reviews.comment_content: This course explain the basic principles that are applied in real world IT project management, such as agile methodology, critical path management, effort estimation etc. Also you will learn how to use basic Microsoft Project Management functions in the labs. Case studies are provided to gain insight on how big corporation manage IT projects.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture videos basically provided 80% of the course content. Classes are held in the form of discussions and in-class activities . Some are pretty interesting, such as having students to build a tower out of spaghetti. Reflections are being done after the activities to show that the management principles are actually being applied into the activities.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is not that good.1 mid term, 1 final, regular online quizzes, 2 lab assignments and attendance are counted toward the grade. For mid term and final, just follow the study guide and recite everything as detail as possible. Little bit of math is needed. Everyone basically got the same mark. Lab assignments are basically easy stuff. ATTENDANCE is what makes you stands out from others. Just raise you hand and answer any question in lecture as much as you could and make professor remembers you. Then you are good to go. I got above 1 SD in mid term, above 0.5 SD in final, full mark for both lab and all quizzes, but didn't answer much questions in lectures, and I got B- :(
reviews.comment_workload: There are lecture videos and follow up quiz every week that you need to complete before the lecture (marks counted). But the questions are very easy so no worry. Also there is a case study almost every week (over 10 pages of reading-_-), but it's not mandatory to read it, though it will be examined in mid term and final so you better recite them. 2 simple lab assignments are also needed (Microsoft project management tools).

reviews.author: Stellar123
reviews.comment_content:
Blended learning model with only one lecture per week + self-learning videos to watch and quizzes on them + Case write-ups (in total 5 only so this one is not a weekly task) to do before class.
As the name implies, this course is about Project management, in particular projects involving information systems. Both hard skills and soft skills required of a project manager has been taught.  For hard skills, things covered include the Waterfall &  Agile model (when to use them, methodologies, deliverables, metrics, pros and cons etc), MS Project etc. Soft skills include ways to tackle difficult scenarios that Project Managers might encounter (eg. As a Project Manager, you are about to have a status report with your client.  However, your project has a major technical problem that causes schedule delay, but you think your team will be able to catch up on full turbo in the coming week.  Should you inform the client of this problem in the upcoming meeting? Will your decision change if the meeting is held tomorrow or in one week's time?)
All in all, I would say this is an insightful course not only applicable to people with the job title of Project Manager.
reviews.comment_teaching: Interactive with business cases and fun in-class activities like marshmallow challenge and domino tower for the introduction of various project management concepts. Lots of in-class discussions as well.  Professor is also helpful and replies emails promptly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Case Write Up 15%
Class Participation (Attendance not counted but participation is) 10%
Quizzes (max 3 attempts per quiz, only highest scoring one kept) 10%
Mid-term Exam 30%
Project (Presentation) 12.5%
Project (Report) 22.5%

Normal grading
reviews.comment_workload: Major workload is on the midterm and the group project (presentation+report). For the group project, if your group has good time management and equal division of labour, the workload should be moderate and manageable.

reviews.author: Roddie
reviews.comment_content: With a lot of management areas covering different phases and different aspects. Cost management, quality management, time management so on and so forth.
reviews.comment_teaching: Web-based teaching along with face to face teaching, the basic content will be taught on the online lecture, while having in-depth discussion in the face-to-face lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is not so good tbh.
Midterm: 91/100 with 1.5SD above
Presentation: 9/10 (good presentation)
Project: 23.5/25 (very good report)
but end up with a grade not as good as I expected.

Rumored that they changed the grading policy from this year with project involved (last year there are only exams), since last semester people got similar mark from the exams and hence they want to have a project for differentiation purpose.

This semester despite I got quite high mark in both exam and report, the grade ends up still so-so, obviously, still, if you did not participate much in the in class discussion, you will not be noticed and hence get a just-so-so grade. (I do participate in in-class discussion, but not as much as GBUS and internationals)
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload with a lot of reading material!!!
Project report length is 30 to 40 pages... Insane workload

reviews.author: Bonriche
reviews.comment_content: This is a really interesting course that covers the many aspects of how to efficiently ensure that a project ends up as a success.
reviews.comment_teaching: Engaging professor. He does not allow students to use any electronic devices in order to increase participation.
reviews.comment_workload:
Unless absolutely necessary, he typically cancels the first lecture of the week so that students can have enough time to watch the video assignments and read the required files that he puts online.

There isn't much effort needed to be done in class either. For example, we spent a large part of one class doing the "Marshmallow Challenge." If you don't know what that is, don't look it up! You need to experience it the right way.
